Ukraine has recovered 17 paintings stolen by armed robbers from the Castelvecchio museum in Verona, Italy last November. The paintings, valued at more than $18 million, were hidden in plastic bags near the border with Moldova. Ukraine has invited Italian officials to the country to begin authentication and recovery of the precious paintings.

Look out, Gabby Douglas! Amazon milk frogs (Trachycephalus resinifictrix) can really stick their landings.

Researchers at Kiel University in Germany used high-speed cameras to film the tree frogs landing on a stick. The frogs grab on with uniquely designed toe pads and use cartwheels and other acrobatics to slow their momentum. And sometimes, they belly flop.

For the first time in over 100 years, famous American women will appear on U.S. paper currency. #HarrietTubman will replace Andrew Jackson on the front of the $20 bill, a group of famous suffragettes will be added to the back of the $10 bill and the $5 bill will show Eleanor Roosevelt and singer Marian Anderson at the Lincoln Memorial. 

Tonight on PBS NewsHour, Treasury Secretary Jack Lew will join Judy Woodruff to discuss the changes.

Drone warfare is a valuable part of the military’s arsenal in the war against international terrorism -- just this month, the Pentagon announced that a drone strike on a jihadist training camp in Somalia killed 150 fighters. Welcome to the world, baby eagle! This morning, one eaglet hatched at the United States National Arboretum in Washington, D.C. The parents are still waiting the arrival of the hatchling's sibling, who is expected to hatch soon.

#MarchMadness means a huge payday for coaches, colleges, networks and advertisers -- everyone except the athletes themselves. Although television rights for the NCAA tournament this year alone brought in nearly a billion dollars, the players won’t see a penny, and many are unhappy with the situation. Economics correspondent Paul Solman examines the cases for and against paying student athletes.

“There’s a potential that my voice can be heard by people who can’t hear me now because I’m Michelle Obama, the first lady. In an event that only happens every several years, a section of the Perito Moreno glacier in Argentina collapsed into its lake this morning. The archway is formed when the glacier acts as a dam for a lake and lake water slowly chips away at the glacier until it ruptures.

Jeb Bush asked an audience in New Hampshire to applaud for him.

During a speech, Bush said the next president "needs to be a lot quieter, but send a signal that we're prepared to act in the national security interest of this country — to get back in the business of creating a more peaceful world."

As he paused, one woman behind him appeared to start clapping. To everyone else, he urged: "Please clap."

Who knew there was proper protocol for wrangling a zebra on the loose? 

Today, Tokyo's Ueno Zoo staged an annual drill which simulates a zebra escaping, while a staff member dressed as the animal runs around the compound. Ueno Zoo has been practicing these drills frequently since 1980 as a way to prepare for scenarios that may occur during an earthquake.

As flood waters in Missouri and the Midwest continue rising, rescue teams are taking stranded people off of rooftops and out of flooded areas.  Many of those people are being allowed to bring their beloved pets with them when they’re rescued.

This policy is a relatively new development, and it’s thanks in part to reforms made after Hurricane Katrina.  It’s estimated that thousands of people refused to evacuate New Orleans in advance of that storm because they weren’t willing to leave their dogs or cats behind. Here’s how that policy got changed:

Join us starting Nov. 30 on PBS NewsHour for an extensive look inside Africa's most populous country. Despite being the richest country on the continent in the midst of an economic boom, Nigeria's citizens are twice as likely to be impoverished today than 30 years ago. Many blame the country's poverty and corruption for fueling the terrorists organization Boko Haram - which in 2014 killed more people than the Islamic State group.  

The four part "Nigeria: Pain and Promise" series (Nov 30 - Dec 3) with Special Correspondent Nick Schifrin explores the country's ongoing battle with Boko Haram, economic promise, corruption and treatment of gay Nigerians.

In 1942, the U.S. ordered 110,000 Japanese-Americans living on the West Coast to internment camps. 

Five-year-old George Takei and his family were sent to camps for nearly four years. Allegiance - A New Musical on Broadway is loosely based on their experience.

Watch our interview with Takei here: http://to.pbs.org/1MqW6t4

status_message:
“For a long time I was terrified to tell people about my illness experience because I was scared they wouldn’t believe me. I needed to become an advocate for myself, especially in conversations about my controversial diagnosis. I had doctors tell me I was having a mental breakdown and needed to find the strength to tell them otherwise. It hasn’t been easy, but finding my voice and sharing my story has been an incredibly powerful tool in my healing process.” – Allie (Photo by Amanda Crommett)

Join our Twitter chat (@NewsHour) tomorrow from  1 p.m. -2 p.m. EDT where we'll speak with experts about the experience of living with "invisible" illness. Interact using #NewsHourChats.
link_name: Timeline Photos

Keisha Henry and her family opened Cafe Dauphine -- the only high-end restaurant in New Orleans Lower 9th Ward since Hurricane Katrina.  

Despite $500 million being spent to revitalize the neighborhood, the Lower 9th Ward is still struggling with crime, ruined streets, and hundreds of vacant, storm-damaged homes. Henry welcomes anyone who wants to move to the Lower 9th Ward and put down roots, but is wary of the intentions of some would-be “saviors” who’ve come to town.

Learn more about her story here: to.pbs.org/1hGznNZ

Fei shares the experience in a new memoir called “Girl in Glass: How My ‘Distressed Baby’ Defied the Odds, Shamed a CEO and Taught Me the Essence of Love, Heartbreak and Miracles.”

A new computer program has systematically charted the evolution of popular music. 

EDITOR'S NOTE: Yes, you're reading those last four categories right. The computer program took an unbiased look at the chords and tone of every song, meaning that artists of both sexes could be considered in both the male and female vocal categories. In this case, Britney Spears was deemed as having the lowest values in male vocals (or having the least masculine vocals) while Pearl Jam was considered to have the lowest value in female vocals (or having the least feminine vocals).

Learn more: http://to.pbs.org/1cmSz0y

"This breathtaking area is home to dozens of species of native and migratory birds, including a small, gray shorebird called a 'piping plover,' which has been on the endangered species list in the United States since 1986."

For a number of years, efforts have been made to protect piping plovers. Like many shorebirds, they're already feeling the impacts of rising sea levels. But until recently, their winter habitat was a mystery.

status_message:
On the morning of Sept. 29, 1982, the parents of 12-year-old Mary Kellerman gave their daughter one extra-strength Tylenol capsule for a standard runny nose and sore throat. Unbeknownst to them, the pill was laced with highly poisonous potassium cyanide, and by 7 a.m., Mary was dead.

Within a week, her death would panic the entire nation, and ultimately change the way we purchase and consume over-the-counter medications.
link_name: How the Tylenol murders of 1982 changed the way we consume medication | PBS NewsHour

status_message: Hari Sreenivasan sends this photo postcard from Guatemala, where he’s working on a NewsHour report on childhood malnutrition. In a country that has the highest rates of malnutrition in the Americas, Hari and his team traveled to the mostly Mayan department of Quiche, where nearly 7 in 10 children are developmentally stunted as a result of poor diet. Despite this grim picture, the Guatemalan government has instituted its Zero Hunger Plan. Look out for our story in a few weeks, in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
link_name: Hari's postcard from Guatemala

status_message: The spotted owl is facing extinction from habitat loss and threats from its cousin, the larger, meaner barred owl. So in order to save the spotted owl, scientists have a controversial solution: kill 3,603 barred owls. http://to.pbs.org/16brPJa

status_message: The Americans with Disabilities Act is 23 years old today. In her blog Judy Woodruff, writes that if you ever get discouraged by today’s gridlock in Washington think of the ABA as a reminder of how far we’ve come as a nation. http://to.pbs.org/15kTRAE

status_message: What are your thoughts? Harry Reid: "Hillary Clinton may have a bigger fan than Harry Reid; I just don’t know who it would be. I think that what she did as a senator, what she did as secretary of state will go down in history books as a remarkable, remarkable job that she did. I, of course, have such admiration for the president. Remember, the last three or four years he was here we reduced the debt and created 22 million jobs – pretty good deal. And I think that they’re a pretty good team, but she’ll handle things probably even better than he did." http://to.pbs.org/16b7OA9

status_message: A new government report on the decline of honeybee colonies in the U.S. stresses that no single cause is responsible for the spiraling losses. Cindy Storer and Nada Bakos were part of a team of CIA intelligence analysts, many of whom were women and were therefore dubbed "The Sisterhood." They're featured on HBO's documentary, "Manhunt," which airs tonight. Learn more here: http://to.pbs.org/13MjA3o

status_message: The investigation into the Boston Marathon bombings and the push to overhaul the country's immigration system have converged in recent days. status_message:
According to AP sources, the two suspects in the Boston Marathon bombing are from a Russian region near Chechnya and have lived in U.S. for at least one year. http://to.pbs.org/11JFHad

Last night, they led Boston police on a wild car chase through suburban neighborhoods before one of them died in a shootout. The other suspect, identified as Dzhokhar A. Tsarnaev, 19, of Cambridge, according to AP, remains at large and is considered extremely dangerous. 

FBI photo below.

status_message:
The Border Security and Economic Opportunity and Immigration Modernization Act of 2013 lays out a path to citizenship for an estimated 11 million undocumented people living in the U.S., reforms the family and employment-based visa, creates new visas for low-income workers and provides funding to secure the U.S. -Mexico border.  http://to.pbs.org/12qrZu9

Below, a group of eight senators on Wednesday filed an 844-page bill that would respond to both political and business interests for reforming the nation's immigration policy.

The Voting Rights Act of 1965 has been one of the most prominent pieces of civil rights legislation. Today, the Supreme Court will revisit this landmark law's constitutionality. 

Our oral history project collected stories from people who witnessed the passage of the act and who share their memories of its impact on the civil rights movement. Take a listen: http://bit.ly/vrastory

status_message:

In honor of the PBS documentary “MAKERS: Women Who Make America,” we asked some of our correspondents to name the women who inspire them. From social activists to barrier-breaking college students and religious leaders, these women have changed not only what the world expects from women, but what women expect from themselves. http://to.pbs.org/Wph4vs

status_message:
What a missing section of one man's brain taught science about memory. http://to.pbs.org/YTunEt

It was in 1953 that a neurosurgeon removed a significant portion of Henry Gustav Molaison's brain. Molaison, known as H.S. up until his death in 2008 at age 82, was intensely studied, making him one of the most important patients in the history of brain science.

U.S. high schools have made significant improvements in graduation rates in the last decade, but progress remains uneven. That's according to a new report released Monday by a non-profit led by former secretary of state Colin Powell. 

The recent trends could eventually lead to the realization of a goal set by every president since George H.W. Bush: to reach a 90 percent high school graduation rate nationwide.  http://to.pbs.org/W80FB1

status_message:
In September 2010, scientists at the EPA came to a startling conclusion: Even a small amount of a chemical compound, Chromium VI, commonly found in tap water may cause cancer. But ten months later, the EPA reversed itself, quietly posting a notice on the Internet that it was pushing back the release of its findings. Learn why here: http://bit.ly/CPIinvs

Below, siblings learn against entrance of a house found to have been polluted by ground water.

status_message:
About 700 new chemicals are created each year. Last year the Environmental Protection Agency set a goal to review 40. It finished only 3. 

In 2011, the EPA was set to cite evidence of cancer risks in hexavalent chromium, a chemical found in tap water that was brought to light in the film "Erin Brockovich." Yet a special EPA panel urged the agency to delay action. Learn about the shocking truths revealed in this investigation: http://bit.ly/CPIinvs
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
On tonight's NewsHour, our Food For 9 Billion series takes a look at chronic famine in Niger http://to.pbs.org/P33oVV 

For decades, Nigeriens have endured an annual hunger season as reserves from the previous harvest are exhausted and the wait -- weeks or even months -- begins for the next one.

Thanks to a technique that encourages farmers to protect, instead of destroy, trees that grow naturally on their land, Niger has boosted its annual food production by 500 million tons -- enough to feed about 2.5 million people. 

But for every step forward, population growth takes progress two steps back. 

(Photo by Fred de Sam Lazaro)
link_name: Timeline Photos
FRONTLINE

status_message:
Although a year has passed since Japan's tsunami sucked tons of wood, nets and other debris into the Pacific Ocean, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) continues to track the rubble and urges others to do so to help focus cleanup efforts. 

Using historical weather patterns, NOAA's Earth System Research Laboratory developed this model of how debris will circulate across the Pacific Ocean.

More: http://to.pbs.org/wKI2Go
link_name: Debris from Japan Tsunami Travels Across the Pacific: http://to.pbs.org/wKI2Go

status_message:
"It's folly to think that we can doom everything to extinction, and we'll be just fine," photographer Joel Sartore said. "When we're saving biodiversity, we're saving ourselves." 

Sartore has been working his way through zoos and rescue organizations across the country as part of a personal mission to photograph all of the roughly 6,000 captive species in the United States before they disappear.

http://to.pbs.org/ABZToC
link_name: Nature Photographer Captures Biodiversity on Film

Healthy job numbers arrived Friday, as the Labor Department reported a net increase of 227,000 jobs in February. The unemployment rate remained at 8.3 percent.

status_message:
It will be years before I understand
failure. The sun's last rage
in the winter trees. My yard 
is a failure of field. It is small
and poorly tended. Years before
this hard kernel of worry
rises to a truer height, I can learn
to make shade with my palms,
but I cannot learn to unmoor my want. 
....

Disrupted motion of three heavenly bodies
In slow soft eclipse
a shadow sphere overtook a pale green disk
My son crawls into my bed with a dream of earth
quickly gulped by a black hole
"Were you on the earth?"
"Yes." "How scary."
Could not comfort that or this. Just go back alone, but not tonight.
Predatory cougars among joggers
feel safer than overwhelming
glacier melt A nest is being threshed,
our private shared dr
link_name: Weekly Poem: 'Disrupted Motion'

Who did I think was listening 
when I wrote down the words 
in pencil at the beginning 
words for singing 
to music I did not know 
and people I did not know 
would read them and stand to sing them 
already knowing them 
while they sing they have no names

From W.S. Merwin, the Library of Congress' 17th Poet Laureate Consultant in Poetry.

status_message:
From NewsHour's Rafael Suarez Jr. : 

Doing a Facebook story on tonight, so I'm using it to ask these questions:
1)Do you want to know more about Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg?
2) Plan to see the movie, premiering tonight, about Zuckerberg and his site?

status_message: Mumbai residents returned to work Monday for the first time since last week's terrorist attacks. Then, Ray Suarez and analysts discuss the often tense relationship between India and Pakistan in light of last week’s attacks.
